pullrequest.title: Fixed several bugs where custom zip groups were overridden.

content.raw: We mainly use the outer expansion, but that might change so I'll test anyway.
content.html: We mainly use the outer expansion, but that might change so I'll test anyway.

pullrequest.title: Fixed several bugs where custom zip groups were overridden.

content.raw:
Ok so I found one thing a bit strange:

I set `global1` to be in zip group 'test1'. Now I set `global2` to be `global1*5` this results in this automatically being assigned to a zip group named 'global1'.  I'd expect the zipgroup to be the same as `global1` ('test1'). If I set `global2` to be `global1*5` before setting `global1` to a list that is exactly what happens. Is this intentional?

Original behavior was that both would be in the same zip group with the name 'global1'.
content.html:
Ok so I found one thing a bit strange:

I set global1 to be in zip group 'test1'. Now I set global2 to be global1*5 this results in this automatically being assigned to a zip group named 'global1'. I'd expect the zipgroup to be the same as global1 ('test1'). If I set global2 to be global1*5 before setting global1 to a list that is exactly what happens. Is this intentional?

Original behavior was that both would be in the same zip group with the name 'global1'.

pullrequest.title: Fixed several bugs where custom zip groups were overridden.

content.raw:
Just to clarify this, in the first scenario, `global1` is in zip group 'test1' and `global2` is in zip group 'global1'?

If so, then yes, this is the \(approximate\) expected behaviour. That is, that we no longer override the fact that the user explicitly requested `global1` to be in a specially named zip group.

Potential improvements could be that `global2` is placed inside the specially named zip group for `global1`, or that `global2` is placed inside a zip group whose name is determined via a process that ignores parent globals with a user specified zip group name, however the code is complicated enough as it is... and it may turn out to be quite hard to do this without introducing another regression.
content.html:
Just to clarify this, in the first scenario, global1 is in zip group 'test1' and global2 is in zip group 'global1'?

If so, then yes, this is the (approximate) expected behaviour. That is, that we no longer override the fact that the user explicitly requested global1 to be in a specially named zip group.

Potential improvements could be that global2 is placed inside the specially named zip group for global1, or that global2 is placed inside a zip group whose name is determined via a process that ignores parent globals with a user specified zip group name, however the code is complicated enough as it is... and it may turn out to be quite hard to do this without introducing another regression.

pullrequest.title: Fixed several bugs where custom zip groups were overridden.

content.raw:
Yes `global2` is automatically assigned to group 'global1'.

I'd expect `global2` to be placed in the group that `global1` is currently in. If it's too complicated I see no real need to change it. it's just something I noticed.
content.html:
Yes global2 is automatically assigned to group 'global1'.

I'd expect global2 to be placed in the group that global1 is currently in. If it's too complicated I see no real need to change it. it's just something I noticed.
